newsitem.title: BURMA: Thailand, Burma celebrate first joint bridge.
newsitem.headline: Thailand, Burma celebrate first joint bridge.

text.p: Thailand and Burma opened a bridge across their river border on Friday in a ceremony billed as a new stage in growing links between the two ASEAN countries.

But despite the fanfare, which included 7,000 Burmese flag-wavers in traditional dress and a fireworks display from the Thais, Burmese soldiers stopped an enthusiastic wave of Thais from crossing the bridge on to Burmese soil.
Burmese officials said the bridge would not be open to public use until their side has completed a road between this border town and the capital Rangoon.
"We would like to express our gratitude to our Thai friends for sponsored the cost of building the bridge," Major-General Saw Tun, minister of construction said in an address.
Construction of the 420 metre (460 yard) bridge, costing about 80 million baht ($2.5 million), began in late 1992 but was delayed over a territorial dispute.
Thai deputy foreign minister Pitak Intarawityanunt said the bridge was a new link between the two countries and said existing bilateral disputes could be discussed another time.

The area has long been vulnerable to ethnic insurgents battling the Burmese military government, although a combination of assaults and ceasefire agreements in recent years has neutralised most of the groups.
Burma last month joined the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) of which Thailand was a founding member in 1967.
